text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx
Diabetes Daily \-- New research on Nutritional and Metabolic Diseases and
Conditions - Type 1 Diabetes is the subject of a report. According to news
reporting from Porto Alegre, Brazil, by NewsRx journalists, research stated,
"Type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) is an autoimmune disorder caused by a complex
interaction between environmental and genetic risk factors. BTB domain and CNC
homolog 2 (BACH2) gene encodes a transcription factor that acts on the
differentiation and formation of B and T lymphocytes."

Financial supporters for this research include Fundo de Incentivo a Pesquisa e
Eventos (FIPE) at Hospital de Clinicas de Porto Alegre, Fundacao de Amparo a
Pesquisa do Estado do Rio Grande do Sul (FAPERGS), Conselho Nacional de
Desenvolvimento Cientifico e Tecnologico (CNPq), Coordenacao de
Aperfeicoamento de Pessoal de Nivel Superior (CAPES), CAPES, CNPq.

The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Hospital
Clinic Porto Alegre, "BACH2 is also involved in the suppression of apoptosis
and inflammation in pancreatic beta-cells, indicating a role for it in the
development of T1DM. Therefore, the aim of this study was to evaluate the
association of the BACH2 rs11755527 single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) with
T1DM. This case-control study comprised 475 patients with T1DM and 598
nondiabetic individuals. The BACH2 rs11755527 (C/G) SNP was genotyped using
real-time PCR with TaqMan MGB probes. Genotype distributions of rs11755527 SNP
were in accordance with frequencies predicted by the Hardy-Weinberg
equilibrium in case and control groups and were similar between groups (P =
0.729). The minor allele frequency was 43.6% in cases and 42.5% in controls (P
= 0.604). Moreover, the G allele frequency did not differ between groups when
considering different inheritance models and adjusting for age, gender, body
mass index, and HLA DR/DQ genotypes of high-risk for T1DM. Although, well-
known high-risk T1DM HLA DR/DQ genotypes were associated withT1DM in our
population [OR= 742 (95% C13.34-17.0)], this association was not influenced by
the rs11755527 SNP."

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The BACH2 rs11755527
SNP seems not to be associated withT1DM in a Brazilian population."

For more information on this research see: The Rs11755527 Polymorphism In the
Bach2 Gene and Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus: Case Control Study In a Brazilian
Population. _Archives of Endocrinology and Metabolism_ , 2020;64(2):138-143.
_Archives of Endocrinology and Metabolism_ can be contacted at: Sbem-Soc
Brasil Endocrinologia & Metabologia, Rua Humaita, 85 Cj 501, Rio De Janeiro,
Rj, 22261-000, Brazil.

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting N.E. Lemos, Hospital Clinic Porto Alegre, Division of
Endocrinology, Porto Alegre, Rs, Brazil. Additional authors for this research
include C. Dieter, G.C.K. Duarte, T.S. Assmann, D. Crispim and L.E. Dorfman.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.20945/2359-3997000000214>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: New Type 1 Diabetes Study Results Reported from Hospital Clinic Porto Alegre (The Rs11755527 Polymorphism In the Bach2 Gene and Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus: Case Control Study In a Brazilian Population): Nutritional and Metabolic Diseases and Conditions - Type 1 Diabetes
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Diabetes Daily -- New research on Nutritional and Metabolic Diseases and Conditions - Type 1 Diabetes is the subject of a report. According to news reporting from Porto Alegre, Brazil, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, “Type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) is an autoimmune disorder caused by a complex interaction between environmental and genetic risk factors. BTB domain and CNC homolog 2 (BACH2) gene encodes a transcription factor that acts on the differentiation and formation of B and T lymphocytes.”

Financial supporters for this research include Fundo de Incentivo a Pesquisa e Eventos (FIPE) at Hospital de Clinicas de Porto Alegre, Fundacao de Amparo a Pesquisa do Estado do Rio Grande do Sul (FAPERGS), Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Cientifico e Tecnologico (CNPq), Coordenacao de Aperfeicoamento de Pessoal de Nivel Superior (CAPES), CAPES, CNPq.

The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Hospital Clinic Porto Alegre, “BACH2 is also involved in the suppression of apoptosis and inflammation in pancreatic beta-cells, indicating a role for it in the development of T1DM. Therefore, the aim of this study was to evaluate the association of the BACH2 rs11755527 single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) with T1DM. This case-control study comprised 475 patients with T1DM and 598 nondiabetic individuals. The BACH2 rs11755527 (C/G) SNP was genotyped using real-time PCR with TaqMan MGB probes. Genotype distributions of rs11755527 SNP were in accordance with frequencies predicted by the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium in case and control groups and were similar between groups (P = 0.729). The minor allele frequency was 43.6% in cases and 42.5% in controls (P = 0.604). Moreover, the G allele frequency did not differ between groups when considering different inheritance models and adjusting for age, gender, body mass index, and HLA DR/DQ genotypes of high-risk for T1DM. Although, well-known high-risk T1DM HLA DR/DQ genotypes were associated withT1DM in our population [OR= 742 (95% C13.34-17.0)], this association was not influenced by the rs11755527 SNP.”

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: “The BACH2 rs11755527 SNP seems not to be associated withT1DM in a Brazilian population.”

For more information on this research see: The Rs11755527 Polymorphism In the Bach2 Gene and Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus: Case Control Study In a Brazilian Population. Archives of Endocrinology and Metabolism, 2020;64(2):138-143. Archives of Endocrinology and Metabolism can be contacted at: Sbem-Soc Brasil Endocrinologia & Metabologia, Rua Humaita, 85 Cj 501, Rio De Janeiro, Rj, 22261-000, Brazil.

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting N.E. Lemos, Hospital Clinic Porto Alegre, Division of Endocrinology, Porto Alegre, Rs, Brazil. Additional authors for this research include C. Dieter, G.C.K. Duarte, T.S. Assmann, D. Crispim and L.E. Dorfman.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.20945/2359-3997000000214. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
